channel.title: Your Complete, Un-budgeted Toolkit [Wiki]
channel.description: Imagine this: _You're a pentester. A long-lost relative has left you a fortune in his will. To keep the money, you have to fulfill just one wish: spend it all on tech (from Amazon, because then you'd be buying a beer or some server time for 0x00sec while still getting some cool stuff for yourself)._ If you have a good idea for some machine (from a teensy or PLC to a multi-tonne gadget), put it down below. complete with a link: - Hardware Communications **(New)** - [Bus Pirate 3.6A](https://www.amazon.com/SparkFun-671-Bus-Pirate-3-6a/dp/B01D1RXHQM/ref=as_li_ss_tl?ie=UTF8&qid=1499332133&sr=8-1&keywords=bus+pirate&linkCode=ll1&tag=0x00sec-20&linkId=428b47d10bbdf8f0a273044db55d36ee) - [Aardvark I2C/SPI Host Adapter](https://www.amazon.com/Aardvark-I2C-SPI-Host-Adapter/dp/B00XV2FD38/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1499334619&sr=8-1&keywords=Aardvark+I2C%2FSPI+Host+Adapter) - [Adafruit FTDI Friend + Extras](https://www.amazon.com/Adafruit-FTDI-Friend-Extras-ADA284/dp/B00NAY1VJ2/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1499334762&sr=8-1&keywords=FTDI+Friend+%2B+extras+-+v1.0) - [Bus Blaster v4](https://www.amazon.com/Dangerous-Prototypes-Seeedstudio-Bus-Blaster-v4-Open/dp/B01BTQTNOM/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1499334843&sr=8-1&keywords=Bus+Blaster+v4) - [FTDI TTL USB-UART](https://www.amazon.com/FTDI-TTL-232RG-VSW5V-WE-CABLE-ASSEMBLY-USB-UART/dp/B00HKJWECQ/ref=sr_1_fkmr0_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1499334496&sr=8-1-fkmr0&keywords=serial+ttl+adapter+TTL-232RG-VSW5V-WE) - Listening Devices **(New)** - [Open Workbench Logic Sniffer](https://www.amazon.com/Seeedstudio-Open-Workbench-Logic-Sniffer/dp/B012U56DSK/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1499335027&sr=8-1&keywords=Open+Bench+Logic+Sniffer) - [Saelea 4 Channel Logic Analyzer](https://www.amazon.com/Saleae-4-Channel-Logic-Analyzer/dp/B018RE3OTY/ref=sr_1_4?ie=UTF8&qid=1499335181&sr=8-4&keywords=saleae+Logic+8) - Bluetooth - [Ubertooth One](https://www.amazon.com/Great-Scott-Gadgets-WRL-10573-Ubertooth/dp/B007R9UPHA/ref=sr_1_fkmr0_2?ie=UTF8&qid=1496772972&sr=8-2-fkmr0&keywords=pineapple+wifi+hak5) - $120.40 - [Adafruit Bluefruit LE Sniffer](https://www.amazon.com/Adafruit-Bluefruit-Sniffer-Bluetooth-nRF51822/dp/B00SKWGPE0/ref=pd_bxgy_147_img_2?_encoding=UTF8&pd_rd_i=B00SKWGPE0&pd_rd_r=A9C91R4G61MGVF4XXRC7&pd_rd_w=OSIQ4&pd_rd_wg=DRHHm&psc=1&refRID=A9C91R4G61MGVF4XXRC7) - $25.73 - SDR - [BladeRF x40](https://www.nuand.com/blog/product/bladerf-x40/) - $420 OR [BladeRF x115](https://www.nuand.com/blog/product/bladerf-x115/) - $650 - [HackRF One Software Defined Radio](https://www.amazon.com/HackRF-Software-Defined-Antenna-Adapter/dp/B01K1CCHR0/ref=pd_sim_147_2?_encoding=UTF8&pd_rd_i=B01K1CCHR0&pd_rd_r=Z4FPPPRBM4CPSYCAQQY5&pd_rd_w=Q4d5Z&pd_rd_wg=hp9co&psc=1&refRID=Z4FPPPRBM4CPSYCAQQY5) - $307.95 - [RTL2832U](https://www.amazon.com/dp/B009U7WZCA) - $19.95 - Physical Infiltration Devices - Lock picks - [Lock Pick Set with Transparent 25PCS Practice Lock](https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0721BQ57H) - shims - Wifi - Yagi WiFi Antenna - AWUS036H - TP Link TL-WN722N-v1 (not sure this link is v1, v2 will NOT work) - [Wifi-Pineapple/PineAP](https://hakshop.com/products/wifi-pineapple) - PLC / MicroComputer / MicroController - Arduino - Raspberry Pi 3 Model B - [2.4G Wireless Backlight Keyboard for Pi](https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B006WAJ1IE) - [LOGO! 6 (230V AC)](https://www.amazon.com/Siemens-6ED10521FB000BA6-LOGO-230RC-BLOCKS/dp/B013HVBC14/ref=sr_1_5?s=industrial&ie=UTF8&qid=1496867215&sr=1-5&keywords=logo+siemens) - [LOGO! 8 (12/24V DC)](https://www.amazon.com/Siemens-6ED1052-1MD00-0BA8-Controller-Display-Blocks/dp/B010SHWEYO/ref=sr_1_1?s=industrial&ie=UTF8&qid=1496867215&sr=1-1&keywords=logo+siemens#feature-bullets-btf) - Accessories - Rii mini wireless keyboard - Portable Power Bank - USB Hub - Tools - Screwdriver Set * Books * Kali Linux: Wireless Penetration Testing Beginner's Guide * Penetration Testing: A Hands-On Introduction to Hacking * The Hacker Playbook 2: Practical Guide To Penetration Testing * [The_Art_of_Human_Hacking](https://www.amazon.com/Social-Engineering-Art-Human-Hacking/dp/0470639539) * [The-shellcoders-Handbook](https://www.amazon.com/Shellcoders-Handbook-Discovering-Exploiting-Security/dp/047008023X) * [Wiley.Android.Hackers.Handbook](https://www.amazon.com/Android-Hackers-Handbook-Joshua-Drake/dp/111860864X) * Hacking: The Art of Exploitation, 2nd Edition * The Browser Hackers Handbook * The Web Application Hackers Handbook Ver. 2 * The Art of Memory Forensics * Mastering Regular Expressions * Red Team Field Manual * The Basics of Hacking and Penetration Testing, Second Edition * [Introduction to programming a Siemens LOGO! PLC](https://www.amazon.com/Introduction-programming-SIEMENS-LOGO-PLC-ebook/dp/B00MZY5VOY) * Modern Assembly Language Programming with the ARM Processor * Windows Internals * Troubleshooting with Windows Sysinternals Tools * Powershell Cookbook * Open Source Intelligence * Complete Privacy & Security Guide * Blue Team Field Manual * Hash Crack: Password Cracking Manual * The Hardware Hacker * How To Hack Like a GOD * Practical Malware Analysis * Practical Reverse Engineering * The Art of Electronics * Stealing the Network: The Complete Series Collector's Edition * Modern Operating Systems * Guide to Kernel Exploitation: Attacking the Core * Password Breaches [h8mail](https://github.com/khast3x/h8mail)

item.title: Your Complete, Un-budgeted Toolkit [Wiki]
item.dc:creator: Scrim
item.description:
In college at a liberal arts school and am “subjected” to diversity requirements. They’re annoying and take away from my technical education, but I do think I become a more well rounded and socially conscious person.

item.title: Your Complete, Un-budgeted Toolkit [Wiki]
item.dc:creator: ricksanchez
item.description:
Bowlslaw:

I would assume it’s the more “intense” technical fields, like malware research and cryptography, right?

Actually I often read and heard people talk about it as well that they might prefer people with a good CS degree over someone who pursued a degree like “IT-Sec” or “Net-Sec” for the sole reason that CS lays a broader foundation and makes people gather different experiences and approaches to things.

Also thinning out people obviously takes place but would you prefer someone with a malware research degree and some work experience or someone with a classic CS degree with similar experience.
I wouldn’t know which one to take until after a personal conversation

Read full topic

item.title: Your Complete, Un-budgeted Toolkit [Wiki]
item.dc:creator: Bowlslaw
item.description:
lantern-shadowclaw:

there are places that use the degree to thin out the stack of resumes and the chances for research I have gotten are better than what I could have done myself

I would assume it’s the more “intense” technical fields, like malware research and cryptography, right? Malware research requires an enormous breadth and depth of skills and how to apply theory, and cryptography requires specialized mathematics knowledge and a thorough understanding of higher mathematical theory(for example, number theory) which are very difficult to learn yourself.

And yeah…massive companies like Google kinda has to. I wonder how many applications they get per year.

Read full topic

item.title: Your Complete, Un-budgeted Toolkit [Wiki]
item.dc:creator: lantern-shadowclaw
item.description:
Now that I am getting ready to graduate soon with a Comp. Sci. degree I have started to see that the companies have been talking to are more impressed at what I’ve taught myself (literally all my knowledge on networking and security) then what I learned in class. @Bowlslaw Is absolutely right , but there are places that use the degree to thin out the stack of resumes and the chances for research I have gotten are better than what I could have done myself. I think it depends on the person and what they want out.

Read full topic

item.title: Your Complete, Un-budgeted Toolkit [Wiki]
item.dc:creator: Bowlslaw
item.description:
I think it’s only worth going to college for two reasons:

  1. You need access to equipment you would otherwise be unable to access, financially, legally, or otherwise, such as the Large Hadron Collider, or a lab full of deadly microbes.

  2. Your professional requires some kind of state license, like medicine or law.

In the Computer Science field(which is incredibly broad, I know), specifically, things like software development and InfoSec, smart companies will hire smart people who are willing and capable, despite a degree. The Computer Science degree’s base is strong, which is why using MIT OCW and other easily available e-books are a great way to acquire said fundamentals.

I think I read that 60+% of software developers are self-taught. College is just…meh, nowadays. Who wants to subject themselves to Diversity Requirements and other brainwashing crap?

Be smart and motivated. Get yourself some skills. Find a non-stupid company that doesn’t confuse Symbols and Things and prove to them you are smart, motivated, and have skills.

That’s what I’ve done and am currently doing. It’s how I got my current QA job, picking up great skills like probing web applications and embedded systems for bugs, using Wireshark to perform real-world packet analysis, etc.

Read full topic

item.title: Your Complete, Un-budgeted Toolkit [Wiki]
item.dc:creator: pry0cc
item.description:
The best way to learn is to be self taught. IMO. Self taught hackers often run circles around somebody who just took the class, because they have a passion and drive to learn their topic.

College is a necessary evil for many, since jobs often require degrees, now a days especially.

Read full topic

item.title: Your Complete, Un-budgeted Toolkit [Wiki]
item.dc:creator: Bowlslaw
item.description:
I agree, except for the college part. College ,as a whole, is a corrupt waste of money and, most importantly, time. With intelligent use of the internet, one can find everything one needs to teach themselves. Also, find a good hackerspace or something.

Read full topic
